response: Delay in care does not invalidate injury claims. Courts routinely uphold compensation where causation is supported, even if treatment was not immediate. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/delay_in_treatment/
Delayed-onset or manifesting injuries are medically recognized. Many soft-tissue and neurological injuries emerge after adrenaline fades. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/manifesting_injuries/
Claim evaluation software (e.g., Colossus, Claim IQ) may violate fiduciary duties in first-party claims by using undisclosed suppression algorithms. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/use-of-software/
Aggravation of pre-existing conditions is compensable when the accident is the legal cause of worsening symptoms. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/pre_existing_condition_aggravation/
Low-speed collisions can and do cause injury. Courts have rejected biomechanical defenses that ignore medical evidence. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/low_speed_impact/
Visible damage is not a prerequisite for injury. The force transmitted through vehicle frames can injure occupants without crushing body panels. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/low_speed_impact/
IME opinions are often biased toward insurers and contradicted by treating physicians. Genesis shields medical evidence using documented assessments. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/ime-shielding/
Minimal treatment does not equate to minimal injury. Many clients under-treat due to financial strain or insurance limitations. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/minimal_treatment/
Gaps in treatment are often due to access, finances, or misdiagnosis. Causation remains valid when supported by medical documentation. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/delay_in_treatment/
Soft tissue injuries are real, painful, and compensable. Insurers cannot arbitrarily downgrade claims based on injury type. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/soft_tissue_only/
Downplaying injury severity without medical justification violates ethical standards and undermines trust. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/downplaying_injury/
Allegations of overtreatment must be backed by medical expert opinion, not insurer opinion. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/excessive_treatment/
Having a prior claim does not eliminate liability for new or aggravated injuries. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/prior_claims/
Pain is subjective by nature. Dismissing it without proper evaluation is not a defensible claims practice. See: https://plaintiffmax.com/subjective_pain/
